intro: Astragalus alopecuroides subsp. alopecuroides, commonly known as the woolly milkvetch, is a perennial legume native to the arid and semi-arid regions of Central Asia. It is characterized by its hairy, often grayish stems and small, pea-like flowers that range in color from pale yellow to reddish-brown. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils and is adapted to drought conditions. It belongs to the Fabaceae family, which includes many nitrogen-fixing plants, contributing to soil fertility. Its subspecies is distinguished by specific morphological traits that set it apart from other related species within the Astragalus genus.
